review_title: Connected me to my culture again
job_title: Held Many Jobs/Multiple Departments in West Vancouver, BC
pros:
I worked at FNHA for almost 9 years working in many roles, under many managers. 

I loved being able to learn more and connect to my culture through opportunities to engage at FNHA - from drumming before meetings and on Mondays to be able to volunteer at community engagement functions it was incredibly healing to connect to my culture through the work I was able to do at FNHA. I thought the company did a great job educating everyone on culture protocol and why it is that there is a need for an organization like the FNHA 

From what I experienced everyone had an equal opportunity to learn about the history of indigenous health care disparities to get a real sense of why we were doing what we were doing - it was easy to collectively connect with the higher vision. 

I personally was afforded many opportunities for growth and projects that not only supported my career but my personal growth as well - public speaking is one I was able to carry into subsequent careers

I was afforded flexible 'work from home' occasionally which also helped me as a new mom - the ability to do so was based on my performance and trust I gained in my work over the years and I felt appreciated by this effort from most of my managers over the years. 

I thought the pay was great, was never told no for holidays, they were very accommodating to me through all I went through in my many years there, even extended health leaves, I mostly felt supported.
cons:
I was there pre-FNHA and post-FNHA - it did grow really fast, and with that growing pains are expected. Overnight people were expected to manage projects and people in a 'sink or swim' way, and that created high-burnout and high-turnover culture.

Very fast-paced and ever-changing priorities given how large the province is and diverse in disasters (floods, fires etc.) 

There were some REALLY bad apples, like really bad, but whenever I approached upper management (c-level) my concerns were heard and I felt safe doing that. 

There was a lot of secrecy and it was a bit intense, but there are also a lot of VERY sensitive topics that are not only health-related but political in nature - it was a bit distracting for me in my role and if you are not a secure person you could perpetually feel like you're being left out due to lack of trust. Some may think this as a 'toxic' environment - in reflection, I can see it was likely due to sensitive topics needing to be discussed.

Favouritism for some special ones in the management eye.

review_title: Takes a lot of patience to work here
pros: Wages, full time options, work with some amazing (though thoroughly overworked) people.  Work is HARD but can be very rewarding.  Attracts hard working, passionate ppl.
cons: HR systems are a mess (not the people), turn over is high.  How they market themselves (progressive, wellness focused) sets ppl up for disappointment.  It’s so difficult to make any real or lasting health changes for patients.  It’s not a health authority like it says it is...  it’s a non profit org.  Leadership is very dysfunctional.  Work is very very political. It’s likely not sustainable as is and I don’t see it being around 5, 10 years from now.

job_title: Full-time Employee in West Vancouver, BC
pros:
-This organization cares about the wellness of its employees, a wellness plan is incorporated in your performance plan. The leadership and my colleagues 'walk the talk' and model wellness.
-There is a healthy teamwork atmosphere and a great corporate culture.
-Everyone works hard and I witness passion and commitment daily.
-FNHA is a learning organization... being part of something new allows for innovation
cons:
- As it could be considered a start-up, it might not be for those who have a hard time with change.
-The organization continues to grow and with that comes streamlining of teams, departments etc. which may not be for some.
-It is a fast-paced place to be which again may not be for some

review_title: If you are looking for meaningful work, join this family
pros:
-daily learning
-meaningful work
-great values and long term vision to improve B.C. First Nations health outcomes
-opportunity to grow in areas you never before contemplated
-Amazing colleagues
-Culturally safe and infused with tradition
-Great organizational shifts on the horizon
-Highly competent leadership
-Solid benefits
-Professional development opportunities, including formal education
-Responsive to suggestions for change
-Interesting and meaningful work
-Committed to improve
-Willingness to work through conflict and difficult situations and set aside personal differences for the sake of B.C. First Nations!!
-Shared values, directives and operating principles are taken seriously
-I have never seen such heart and spirit
-This place teaches you humility
cons:
-Organization is still young and working out the kinks, as to be expected!
-Constant recalibration of business lines in an effort “to get it right” makes for a challenging and sometimes stressful work environment, which is why the organization constantly encourages staff to take care of personal health and well-being. 
-Sometimes managers are not available because they are being pulled in a million directions (so you have to feel comfortable with lack of direction at times and riding the wave of confusion; good news is that everyone is in the same canoe paddling and supporting each other like family
-pay is not spectacular and below standards
-This place teaches you humility

pros: Excellent advocates for First Nations interests. Strong and effective CEO / founder.
cons: VP publicly made fun of staff and appeared to enjoy ganging up on others. They didn't collaborate well internally with teams from other units, which created silos and disfunction throughout the organization. They also didn't work well with external partners, causing internal & external frustration, affecting FNHA's reputation. They also didn't respect work life boundaries, emailing staff on weekends and holidays.

job_title: Project Manager in West Vancouver, BC
pros: The best thing is coming to work and being engaged with a team of enthusiastic colleagues who are excited to work that has never been done before. I appreciate that I am able to be involved in and lead large projects that I would likely not get a chance to participate in this early in my career at other health authorities. I have a lot of freedom and support in my job as well from my managers.
cons: Personality conflicts among Senior Executives can get in the way of doing good work.
